rounds.response:
Let me check this offer against my own valuations first.

Valuation of what I’d give away:
1 Brick is worth 22 points to me.

Valuation of what I’d receive:
1 Sheep is worth 17 points to me.

Net change: +17 – 22 = –5 points.
This trade would lower my total value, so it is disadvantageous.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
I currently have:

- Wheat 13 (5)  
- Wood 13 (12)  
- Sheep 19 (17)  
- Brick 15 (22)  
- Ore 14 (36)  

Value I would gain by accepting “1 Sheep → 1 Brick” is +5 VP per unit (22–17 = 5).  
That is favorable, but only marginally and doesn’t shift my overall portfolio much.  
Before I lock in such a small deal, let me see if I can arrange something more
value-positive for me by post-processing larger trades.  
Since I was silent last turn, I will now present an active proposal rather than
accept this single-unit swap.

[Offer: 6 Sheep, 4 Ore -> 6 Brick, 2 Wheat]

rounds.response:
I’m playing the Negotiation Game as Player 1.  
My resources and unit values right now are:

- 13 Wheat @ 5  
- 13 Wood  @ 12  
- 19 Sheep @ 17  
- 15 Brick @ 22  
- 14 Ore   @ 36  

Total present value ≈ 1 518.  
Brick (22) and Ore (36) are my highest–value items, while Wheat (5) is cheapest.

Current negotiating history (6 turns consumed so far) shows Player 0 is only willing to talk when the deal looks very favorable to them, so I’ll try an offer that both incentivizes them to accept and still improves my total value.

Plan  
- Give up 4 Ore or 4 Sheep to Player 0.  
- Obtain either Brick (my best near-cash asset) or Ore, whichever they’re more willing to part with.  
- Keep the marginal values favorable: net gain ≥0 for me.

Concrete new offer:

[Offer: 4 Sheep -> 3 Brick]

rounds.response:
Let’s review the situation.

My current totals  
- Wheat 13 (5)  
- Wood 13 (12)  
- Sheep 19 (17)  
- Brick 15 (22)  
- Ore 14 (36)

Brick (22 each) has the highest unit value of anything I produce in-house, so I should defend it.  
Sheep (17 each) is plentiful and ranks lower than brick, so trading some of it for brick is value-accretive as long as the per-unit price is attractive.

Every offer I’ve made so far has been rejected, so either the quantity hasn’t been tempting enough or Player 0 simply doesn’t like sheep. I still have 19 sheep, though, and only 15 brick—room to improve.

A small, clearly positive offer might land better than the larger packages I floated before.

[Offer: 2 Sheep -> 2 Brick]

rounds.response:
My turn is coming up again.  
Let me look at the score change from the last completed trade and decide the next move.

Current inventory (post last trade):
- Sheep: 19 – 2 = 17 (value 17)  
- Brick: 15 + 2 = 17 (value 30)  
- Others unchanged.

Notes
- I’m still heavy in Sheep (17x, value 17) and would like to swap a few for higher-value Brick.
- Player 0 just accepted a 2 Sheep → 2 Brick deal, so they’re probably willing to take more sheep at a similar 1 : 1 ratio.

I will now politely ask if they’re interested in another sheep-for-brick trade and slightly sweeten the ratio to keep them engaged.

[Offer: 5 Sheep -> 4 Brick]
